90.text: off the ends of chromosomes. So that's a simple concept,

95.text: but we can dive down into it further and think a little bit

98.text: more about what that actually means. So when we think

102.text: of the end of the DNA, there can be two kinds: There

105.text: can be the natural end of the DNA, such as the ones we

108.text: see here, the ends of the chromosomal DNA; and there

112.text: can also be DNA breaks. Now, the job of a cell is to seal

121.text: up any DNA breaks that happen by accident. And so a

125.text: major part of this capping function, which is one of the

129.text: aspects of telomere functions, is to prevent the telomeres

133.text: from undergoing those very DNA transactions of very

137.text: DNA reactions that are undergone by a broken DNA end.

144.text: So if you have a break in the DNA, it can be sutured

147.text: together by, for example, recombination or just simply the

151.text: two broken ends can be ligated right back together by

154.text: end-to-end fusions. Also, such DNA breaks are subject to

160.text: degradation. Now the telomere protects, it caps, the end

165.text: of the chromosome and protects against all of these kinds

168.text: of things that would normally happen to a broken DNA

172.text: end. How does it do that? The DNA sequences that you

178.text: find at the ends of chromosomes, repeated over and

181.text: over, are fairly similar in nature to each other. They're

186.text: relatively simple sequences, and they're too simple to

189.text: code for any proteins. They're not genes in the sense of

195.text: coding for any proteins or RNAs. In humans for example,

201.text: this repeated sequence is found up to a few thousand

204.text: times, tandemly repeated over and over at the ends of the

209.text: chromosomes. Another feature of the chromosomal DNAs

214.text: is that, of course, unlike most of the DNA of a

218.text: chromosome, which is duplex DNA, double-stranded

220.text: DNA, the very end is single-stranded. And in fact the

224.text: DNA strand is oriented 5' to 3', going toward the end of

230.text: the chromosome. And that turns out to be important. So,

238.text: we have now the telomere structure to begin with: We

241.text: have again, if we blow up the end of a chromosome, we

245.text: have these highly repeated sequences made up of a G-

250.text: rich sequence that's the repeat unit repeated over and

253.text: over again. As I said, it doesn't encode any protein

257.text: sequences, but each of these repeated sequences is like

263.text: a little attractive magnet for specific proteins that bind

267.text: sequence specifically to the telomeric DNA. They bind to

271.text: the telomeric repeats for the double-stranded portion, and

275.text: some of them bind the single-stranded portion, and that's

279.text: actually the G-rich strand that's forming the overhanging

296.text: about the protein-DNA interactions, some of the molecular

302.text: interactions in this complex, but we don't really

305.text: understand the higher order structure, so that's still a

307.text: challenge in the field. So I've just shown you a functional

333.text: first is if the tract of telomeric repeat is simply too short,

338.text: there's just not enough of the length of the repeats to form

573.text: the issue here? Well, the mechanism of DNA replication,

580.text: the machinery of DNA replication, has a particular quirk to

584.text: it. It's very good at faithfully copying almost all the way

589.text: along the length of the chromosomal DNA (or any linear

593.text: DNA), but the make-up of the DNA replication machinery

599.text: is such that is cannot copy the very, very end of the linear

604.text: DNA, such as a eukaryotic chromosomal DNA. Now the

610.text: predicted and observed consequence of that inability is

614.text: that, each time the DNA replicates, which is has to do as

620.text: the cell divides, and then the cell divides, the daughter

624.text: DNAs are predicted to become shorter and shorter and

627.text: shorter. And this is just a simple consequence of the

632.text: nature of the DNA replication machinery that is otherwise

637.text: so good at replicating all the way along all the length of

641.text: the chromosomal DNA. But the very ends cannot be

645.text: completely replicated without some form of compensatory

649.text: mechanism. So what's the consequence of this loss?

653.text: Well, obviously, something has to compensate in the long

656.text: run, otherwise, we wouldn't be here. But even on a

659.text: shorter timeframe, as cells divide and divide, the DNA

663.text: gets shorter and shorter, one might predict that there

665.text: would come a point when there wouldn't be enough of

670.text: something or other at the end that then the chromosomes

674.text: would no longer be able to support cell division, and the

678.text: cells might eventually undergo what's called senescence.

682.text: And indeed James Watson in 1972, just considering the

686.text: mechanism of DNA replication, proposed this constant

690.text: shortening problem, and Olovnikov around the same time

696.text: proposed that in fact perhaps such loss of terminal DNA,

701.text: without knowing at that stage what the molecular nature

704.text: of the terminal DNA was, Olovnikov proposed that

707.text: perhaps such gradual loss could be something that

710.text: underlies the eventual senescence of cells that is seen

714.text: sometimes when, for example, human cells are grown in

717.text: culture. This was a prescient idea because, in fact, this

722.text: indeed has been found to be one of the causes of why

727.text: human cells cannot replicate themselves, the cells cannot

732.text: proliferate, indefinitely in culture. So, shortening of

739.text: telomeric DNA is something that will be problematic for

745.text: cells. How is this problem solved? Well, it's solved by an

753.text: enzyme called telomerase. So I'd like to introduce you to

757.text: telomerase now, and how it was found. Telomerase was
